title: Combined Skills Problem: Functions and Quadratics

content.problem:
A projectile is launched with an initial velocity. Its height h(t) in meters after t seconds is given by the function h(t) = -4.9t² + 24.5t + 1.5.

1. Find the maximum height reached by the projectile.
2. At what time does the projectile hit the ground?
3. What is the height of the projectile after 2 seconds?
content.solution:
Step 1: Find the maximum height by finding the vertex of the quadratic function.
The function h(t) = -4.9t² + 24.5t + 1.5 has a = -4.9, b = 24.5, and c = 1.5.

The t-coordinate of the vertex is at t = -b/(2a) = -(24.5)/[2(-4.9)] = 24.5/9.8 = 2.5 seconds

The maximum height is h(2.5):
h(2.5) = -4.9(2.5)² + 24.5(2.5) + 1.5
h(2.5) = -4.9(6.25) + 61.25 + 1.5
h(2.5) = -30.625 + 61.25 + 1.5
h(2.5) = 32.125 meters

Step 2: Find when the projectile hits the ground (h(t) = 0)
Solve: -4.9t² + 24.5t + 1.5 = 0

Using the quadratic formula: t = (-b ± √(b² - 4ac))/(2a)
t = (-24.5 ± √(24.5² - 4 × (-4.9) × 1.5))/(2 × (-4.9))
t = (-24.5 ± √(600.25 + 29.4))/(-9.8)
t = (-24.5 ± √629.65)/(-9.8)
t = (-24.5 ± 25.09)/(-9.8)

t = (-24.5 + 25.09)/(-9.8) ≈ -0.06 seconds (before launch, not valid)
t = (-24.5 - 25.09)/(-9.8) ≈ 5.06 seconds

The projectile hits the ground after about 5.06 seconds.

Step 3: Find the height after 2 seconds by evaluating h(2)
h(2) = -4.9(2)² + 24.5(2) + 1.5
h(2) = -4.9(4) + 49 + 1.5
h(2) = -19.6 + 49 + 1.5
h(2) = 30.9 meters

interactive.question: If the same projectile is launched from a platform that is 10 meters high instead of 1.5 meters, what would be the new time (in seconds) when the projectile hits the ground? (Assume the function becomes h(t) = -4.9t² + 24.5t + 10)
